title: Figma Brings Photoshop‑Style Precision Editing to the Canvas With Three New AI Image Tools

paragraphs.content: Figma has rolled out three new **AI-powered image editing tools**—Erase object, Isolate object, and Expand image—designed to give designers more precise control over visuals without leaving the Figma canvas.The tools allow users to remove unwanted elements, separate and restyle specific subjects, and extend image backgrounds to new aspect ratios while preserving visual integrity.They sit inside a revamped contextual image toolbar that now consolidates core functions such as Remove background, Crop, and AI image generation and editing in one place.The capabilities are available in Figma Design and Figma Draw for Full‑seat users on Professional, Organization, and Enterprise plans with AI enabled, with plans to expand to more Figma products next year.

paragraphs.content: In a short launch video, Figma pitches the update as a way to “make, edit, and refine visuals without ever leaving your file,” underscoring its ambition to keep more of the creative workflow on the canvas.Coverage from AI-focused outlets describes the release as an **AI-assisted image editing suite** that automates tedious tasks like object cleanup and background expansion, rather than replacing designers’ judgment.By focusing on non‑prompt, selection-based controls, the company is positioning its AI as an embedded utility that quietly accelerates production work.Analysts say this approach could significantly tighten feedback loops for product, marketing, and growth teams that iterate across multiple formats and channels.

sections.title: How Erase, Isolate, and Expand Change Day‑to‑Day Design Work

paragraphs.content: Figma’s new tools are aimed squarely at the everyday friction of cleaning up and adapting imagery across devices, campaigns, and product surfaces.Erase object lets users lasso a stray element—like an off‑brand prop or distracting background object—and remove it while AI reconstructs the missing area.Isolate object enables designers to pull out a person or product, reposition it, and adjust attributes such as lighting, color, or focus independently from the background.Expand image, meanwhile, extends the edges of an image so a single asset can be repurposed from a square format into a wide hero banner or mobile story without manual cloning or distortion.

paragraphs.content: Industry write‑ups note that these edits now happen directly on the Figma canvas, reducing the need to bounce assets through Photoshop or other raster editors for what are often described as “minor visual tweaks.” For marketers, tools like Expand image make it easier to adapt a single product shot to different ad specs and social formats, cutting down on back‑and‑forth with design teams. Object removal and isolation also mean performance teams can test different focal points or layouts—such as shifting a product to make space for copy—without opening a separate creative ticket. Commentators argue that this kind of in‑file, context‑aware editing effectively turns Figma from a prototyping surface into a fuller production hub for visual assets.

sections.title: Competitive Stakes: Catch‑Up on Features, Differentiation on Workflow

paragraphs.content: Analysts point out that rivals like Adobe and Canva have offered object removal and background expansion features for several years, making Figma’s move an important step in closing a perceived feature gap. At the same time, Figma is deliberately steering away from prompt‑driven generative imagery, emphasizing granular, selection-based editing controls instead. Commentators contrast this with standalone generative models, noting that while those tools excel at creating new scenes, Figma is targeting the more prosaic but critical work of refining assets for production use. The launch also arrives amid a broader platform race to embed AI directly where users work, including recent moves to expose creative features inside conversational interfaces.

Looking ahead, observers expect Figma to extend these AI image capabilities across more of its ecosystem, potentially deepening ties between design, collaboration, and implementation tools. As organizations standardize on Figma for product and experience design, built‑in precision editing could reduce reliance on separate creative suites for all but the most advanced retouching. Experts say this may shift how teams structure workflows, with more image decisions happening during live design reviews rather than in downstream production phases. Ultimately, the update signals Figma’s intent to compete not by out‑generating AI art platforms, but by owning the practical, everyday editing tasks that shape how digital products and campaigns actually ship.
